XmlLogger makes the assumption that no messages will be logged until 
buildStarted and no messages will be logged after buildFinished.

Our Ant integration did not meet either of these assumptions.

Reworking to match the assumptions as other listeners/loggers could make 
similar assumptions based on the Apache Ant commandline behavior.

We have a workaround in hand with a customized XmlLogger.
Has been a problem for quite some time.

Moving to M5. Solution is doable but touches the core Ant integration and if 
something goes wrong...

Did some major re-wiring here.
The build loggers used by Eclipse were relying on the properties being set 
before there starting logging messages. Setting properties before buildStarted 
broke the XMLLoggers.

Introduced configuration of the loggers using Java methods instead of setting 
configuration from Ant properties.

Changes to:
org.eclipse.ant.internal.core.ant.InternalAntRunner: properties are set after 
the buildListeners/loggers are set and buildStarted has occurred. Early error 
messages are logged after build started.

org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.antsupport.InternalAntRunner: same as other 
InternalAntRunner

created AbstractEclipseBuildLogger for logger configuration

adapted TestBuildLogger to when properties are set

NullBuildLogger: subclass of AbstractEclipseBuildLogger
AntProcessBuildLogger: adapt to how processId is set
AntProcessDebugBuildLogger: adapt to how processId is set

AntLaunchDelegate: process id constant changed
AntProcess: process id constant changed

RemoteAntBuildListener: process id constant changed
RemoteAntBuildLogger: adapt to being configured instead of setting state from 
Ant properties

As well RemoteAntDebugBuildLogger: adapt to being configured instead of 
setting state from Ant properties

Tests added to the Ant core OptionTests, Ant UI BuildTests and SeparateVMTests.

Also removed unnecessary fireBuildStarted methods in the InternalAntRunner 
classes.
